dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I just... I cannot even believe this. Seriously? Seventy-two percent of the world's food comes from small farmers?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I just... I cannot even believe this. Seriously? Seventy-two percent of the world's food comes from small farmers?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The industrial farms and multinational agribusinesses based in the Global North do not account for most of the worlds food production, 70% of which comes from millions of small farmers, especially in the developing world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and? What's, like, your point? That industrial farming just, uh, magically disappears?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and? What's, like, your point? That industrial farming just, uh, magically disappears?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: My point is that this whole myth, you know, that industrial agriculture feeds the world? It's, it's a 'first-world conceit'! The article says it!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: My point is that this whole myth, you know, that industrial agriculture feeds the world? It's, it's a 'first-world conceit'! The article says it!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Timothy Wise of the Small Planet Institute and Tufts University argues in his new book, the myth that we feed the world is the ultimate first-world conceit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but those industrial methods, they still provide massive yields. Think about the scale needed. You can't just, like, deny that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but those industrial methods, they still provide massive yields. Think about the scale needed. You can't just, like, deny that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But at what cost? Monocropping, excessive chemicals, 'increasingly unsafe food,' it says! And soil damage!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But at what cost? Monocropping, excessive chemicals, 'increasingly unsafe food,' it says! And soil damage!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This dogma has led to pervasive monocropping and excessive use of chemicals in food production. These practices damage the environment, reduce soil quality, make crops more vulnerable to natural hazards and pests, pose greater risks to farmers livelihoods, and produce increasingly unsafe food.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Damage, sure, but also, um, initial 'dramatic' yield increases, remember Malawi? It worked for a while.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Damage, sure, but also, um, initial 'dramatic' yield increases, remember Malawi? It worked for a while.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over a decade ago, the country sought to increase maize production by giving smallholders coupons to buy seeds and chemical fertilizers. Yields rose dramatically at first, prompting reports of a Malawi Miracle (multinational seed and fertilizer companies benefited, too).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Worked for multinational seed companies, not the farmers! They ended up having to buy more chemicals just to maintain yields!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Worked for multinational seed companies, not the farmers! They ended up having to buy more chemicals just to maintain yields!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Farmers had to buy more seeds and fertilizer just to maintain yields, and there is now little evidence that rural hunger in Malawi has decreased.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But without those, um, large-scale systems, how do you sustain the population? Small farmers, you know, they can't just, like, magically feed everyone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But without those, um, large-scale systems, how do you sustain the population? Small farmers, you know, they can't just, like, magically feed everyone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They can! Kerala, Mexico, China – they're showing that sustainable, local methods are succeeding! They have the tools!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They can! Kerala, Mexico, China - they're showing that sustainable, local methods are succeeding! They have the tools!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the Indian state of Kerala, local communities are leading a resurgence in rice farming... Small farmers in Mexico are playing a crucial role in preserving much-needed biodiversity... And China has given small farmers training and facilities... Whats more, many of these farmers already have the tools to achieve green agricultural goals, according to Wise, if only they were allowed to use them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Succeeding where? In isolated examples? The article itself makes it clear it's 'easier said than done.' Giant agribusiness interests will prevent it!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Succeeding where? In isolated examples? The article itself makes it clear it's 'easier said than done.' Giant agribusiness interests will prevent it!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But this is easier said than done. Giant agribusiness interests may be powerful enough to prevent such a revolution from even taking root.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So we just, uh, roll over? Let Big Food continue to create 'widespread malnutrition at both ends of the spectrum'?!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So we just, uh, roll over? Let Big Food continue to create 'widespread malnutrition at both ends of the spectrum'?!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is that food is so unequally distributed and irrationally consumed that there is widespread malnutrition at both ends of the spectrum: the worlds most deprived people die or suffer from cognitive impairment because of undernutrition, while others face death or disease because of obesity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Malnutrition because people, um, want cheaper food, though. It's not just Big Food. Consumers are 'accustomed' to it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Malnutrition because people, um, want cheaper food, though. It's not just Big Food. Consumers are 'accustomed' to it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It may seem futile even to attempt this, because consumers around the world are so accustomed to the cheaper foods produced by global agribusinesses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No! It's about aggressive marketing, and, like, unhealthy patterns. Obesity and undernutrition in the same family! It's right here!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! It's about aggressive marketing, and, like, unhealthy patterns. Obesity and undernutrition in the same family! It's right here!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And food consumption around the world is becoming less healthy and sustainable, owing to aggressive marketing... Industrial farming also fuels unhealthy and dangerous consumption patterns, sometimes even leading to obesity and undernutrition within the same family.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, but what's your grand plan then? Just dismantle everything? It sounds, um, naive, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, but what's your grand plan then? Just dismantle everything? It sounds, um, naive, honestly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Loosen their grip! Give small farmers the room to produce sustainably! It’s the 'answer' the article says is 'simple'!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Loosen their grip! Give small farmers the room to produce sustainably! It's the 'answer' the article says is 'simple'!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The answer to the modern global food problem seems simple: loosen the grip of big corporations over production, distribution, and consumption, and give small farmers the room to produce sustainably.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Simple? No, that's, uh, hopelessly idealistic. Policymakers encourage industrial agriculture for a reason. They believe it's the only way.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Simple? No, that's, uh, hopelessly idealistic. Policymakers encourage industrial agriculture for a reason. They believe it's the only way.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...policymakers seem happy to encourage the widespread belief that only industrial agriculture can feed the world and meet increasing demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And that belief is 'dogma'! It's causing all these problems! It's hubris!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that belief is 'dogma'! It's causing all these problems! It's hubris!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This dogma has led to pervasive monocropping and excessive use of chemicals in food production... A deep-seated complacency at the heart of the worlds business-driven food system is fast turning into hubris.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hubris or reality? Those interests are too powerful. You can't just, um, revolt against Big Food and expect them to, like, just vanish.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hubris or reality? Those interests are too powerful. You can't just, um, revolt against Big Food and expect them to, like, just vanish.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Giant agribusiness interests may be powerful enough to prevent such a revolution from even taking root.
